titleproper.value: Guide to the Michael Harrington Papers <num>TAM 209</num>

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-05-01T20:03:05</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

abstract.value: Michael Harrington (1928-1989) was a U.S. socialist, editor, writer, founder and leader of Democratic Socialists of America (U.S. affiliate to the Socialist International), and political leader best known for his book <title render="italic">The Other America: Poverty in the United States</title>(1962). These papers include his notebooks, correspondence, and documentation of his various political and journalistic endeavors.

p.value: Materials are open for with no restrictions.

Published citations should take the following form: <lb/><lb/>Identification of item, date; Michael Harrington Papers; TAM 209; box number; folder number; <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library <lb/>70 Washington Square South <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.
Donated by Stephanie Harrington in 1998. The accession number associated with this gift is 1999.004.
<bibref><emph render="italic">See also</emph>: Isserman, Maurice, <title render="italic">The Other American : The Life of Michael Harrington</title>(New York : Public Affairs, 2000), 449 p.</bibref>

Series two, arranged alphabetically by topic, contains typescripts for unpublished and published articles, book reviews, lectures, speeches, and for a debate with Carl Gershman; three audio recordings of lectures on Marxism; typescripts for <title render="italic">The New American Poverty</title> (1984) and <title render="italic">Socialism, Past and Future</title> (partial, 1989); three oral history interview transcripts (1965, 1988); documents from and unpublished Harrington reports on several Socialist International leadership meetings, including one discussing the Palestine Liberation Organization (1979); additional reading notes; publishing and miscellaneous correspondence; clippings; materials relating to Harrington's teaching career; U.S. Senate testimony (1987); and an invitation to the funeral of Robert F. Kennedy.
